Award.AwardTitle: Measure-valued solutions of hyperbolic conservation laws
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is aimed at the analysis of hyperbolic systems of conservation laws. The focus is on: (1) vanishing viscosity limits to the multi-dimensional Euler equations of gas dynamics; and (2) new representation formulas for solutions of conservation laws. The first project aims at the characterization of limits of families of the vanishing viscosity, radial solutions to the multidimensional Euler equations with large, discontinuous data. The methods of compensated compactness will be adopted for systems of equations that do not possess invariant regions, using only the balance of total energy. In the second project the Principal Investigator will establish a new kinetic formulation for hyperbolic conservation laws. In this approach solutions of conservation laws are represented by probability measures on the phase space which, in turn, are represented as divergences of vector fields obtained as values of a contraction semigroup on suitable Hilbert spaces.


Hyperbolic systems of conservation laws are fundamental equations in physics. They model diverse phenomena in dynamics of gases, elasticity, and electromagnetism. Because of their importance in applications these equations have been extensively studied. However, there is no complete theory that allows one solving the equations for generic data and describing properties of the solutions. The project introduces several innovative analytical tools to approach these issues and creates a theoretical basis for solving a large variety of equations of this type. The research will potentially have impact on the areas of computational and applied mathematics where the hyperbolic systems are involved. Results of this research will be disseminated through presentations at national and international conferences, seminars and publications in scientific journals. Graduate student projects will be integrated into this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by the grant was focused on analytical methods of constructing solutions to the  systems of Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) that originate from the models of motion of gases and fluids. It included the investigation of properties of the existence, the stability of solutions and the structural characteristics of systems of equations.


Despite the purely abstract nature of the research, there is a pressing need in applied science for the formal theory of solutions of differential equations. As computer simulations play an increasingly larger role in science and engineering, being more cost effective than the experimental models,  it is critical to ascertain that numerical simulations produce valid approximations of the actual solutions of PDEs. It turns out that it is a rather complicated issue, as, typically, solutions of PDEs exhibit unwanted, singular behavior. Solutions are in general not unique, not stable, or even do not exist as regular functions. However, with the extensive interest and effort of the scientific community,  no comprehensive analytical theory of solutions has yet been developed.

The research activity supported by the grant was divided into three projects. In Project 1 and Project 2 the PI, with collaborators,  considered the Euler equations of the gas dynamics and the shallow water equations of fluid motion. The goal was the development of rigorous theory for generating solutions of these systems using the classical viscosity method, which is often used in numerical implementations. The PI established the framework that validates the viscous approximation for weak, radially symmetric solutions of the Euler equations, and weak solutions of the shallow water equations in dimension one. The analysis was based on the method of compensated compactness and the derivation of new properties of the equations.

In Project 3 the PI studied the multidimensional Euler equations. A number of results were obtained that enhance our  understanding of the problem, and introduce novel methods that will lead to future development in the field. Among the results is the existence of solutions of approximately isentropic Euler equations, the existence of measure-valued solutions derived from kinetic models of the Euler equations, and the representation of solutions as gradient flows in a suitable functional framework.

Intellectual Merit

The main contribution of the proposal was the advance of the mathematical theory of the equations of gas and fluid dynamics. The PI extended the existing techniques, introduced new analytical concepts and designed new tools for solving an important class of differential equations.

Broader Impact

The PI prepared 6 papers that are based on the results obtained during the grant term. The papers were submitted for publications in peer-reviewed journals, and either has already appeared or will appear in press soon.  The PI participated in national and international conferences and presented the outcomes to a broad scientific community, acknowledging the support of the NSF. A website was maintained by the PI, where the information on the progress of the research, and preprints of the manuscripts were available to general public.
